awd_titl_txt: SoCS:  Crowdsourcing Creativity:  Experiments in Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet makes possible a different kind of design, based on a new phenomenon: crowdsourcing creativity, where many individuals perform small design tasks for fun, nominal compensation, or both. What if the iterative application of a crowd's energy is used to generate, combine and refine ideas and possible solutions to social and technical problems? If the sequential application of crowdsourcing to idea generation works well, then many difficult design challenges might be addressed. If crowdsourcing has limits, then finding these limits will provide a more focused path for the growth of peer production. During the course of this project, participants, drawn from the general public, will generate initial ideas, then combine the many different ideas of their peers, seeking to solve difficult and open-ended design problem through a large scale process of combination, evaluation, selection, and combination again, cycling through these steps until a solution is converged upon. 

The Intellectual Merit of this research lies in the design and results of experiments that study crowdsourcing in the idea discovery process. The Broader Impact of this research lies in its potential harnessing of human intellectual power to attack challenging problems whose solution will affect every one of us. The project is potentially transformative, in that the crowdsourcing of important problems might accelerate by orders of magnitude our progress on pressing social and technological issues.

por.por_cntn:
Current Internet-based technologies make it possible to assemble large numbers of people, in the form of online crowds, and focus these crowds on creative tasks. During this project, the investigators designed and ran a series of experiments focused on understanding ways of organizing and directing crowds on creative tasks in several domains. The findings have potential application in a wide variety of industrial settings, because crowds provide a distinct and complementary vehicle for innovation in relation to company-internal research and development teams. 

Crowds by definition have members with varied backgrounds: for a particular problem, it is likely that many of those who are given the roles of designers or evaluators will have little domain knowledge related to the problem at hand. What kind of organizational mechanisms can accommodate such variance? One mechanism explored in depth over the course of this project was a human-based genetic algorithm. Computer-based genetic algorithms mimic evolution by computationally creating a population of solutions, and then modifying, combining and evaluating them; those evaluated highly are more likely to survive for further modification and recombination. Human-based algorithms work the same way, except that the processes of modifying, combining, and evaluating designs are performed by people, not machines. Computer systems play a role by creating tasks based on the statistics of the solutions in progress, and then assigning crowd members to accomplish the remaining tasks. This method can allow many individuals to work in parallel on tasks, exploring the space of possible design solutions.

Experiments performed as part of the project showed that this mechanism was successful in some domains: participants were able and willing to perform these design tasks, and the designs improved from generation to generation, as measured by crowds and by experts. The experiments suggested how this result occurred. As with computer-based genetic algorithms, not all recombinations or modifications are better than the parents they descend from. But some are, and the selection mechanism of the human based algorithm works as a ratchet, passing on improved designs to the next generation. In other experiments, the investigators found that novel features tended to propagate more than usual features, but only if the features were not impractical. In other words, designers favored novelty but only if practicality was not sacrificed.

In particular, these results were strongest in tasks related to the design of everyday objects such as chairs and clocks. Recombinations often produced interesting new designs that propagated into later generations. Results were different when crowd members were asked to design advertisements. In such environments, modification increased quality, but recombination did not. One possible explanation for this finding is that the design of everyday objects present clearer opportunities for modularity, and this modularity is important for recombination: for example, the seat of one chair was often recombined with the back of another. In more abstract tasks such as the creation of advertising copy, crowd members sometimes had difficulty finding ways of integrating disparate concepts.

In the later stages of the project, the investigators looked at online design communities. Through observational studies, the investigators found that both modification and recombinations of designs in these communities had characteristics similar to the practices observed in the experiments. Depending on the domain, both modifications and recombinations sometimes, but not always, produced better child designs, and the community exerted a natural selection process by paying particular attention to designs that exhibited both novelty and practicality.
